**The Thatched Hut Collection**
*Scripture Title: The Thatched Hut Collection*
By Wang Dan’gua of the Jin Dynasty
One fascicle
Source text: *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Taiping* Section

---

**The Thatched Hut Collection**
By Master Wang of Five Peaks and White Clouds

**Lyrics: Eleven "Court Full of Fragrance"**

Composed on the twenty-second day of the twelfth lunar month, the anniversary of the descent of the Venerable Ancestor Chongyang, the Wondrous-Act Realized Man of Compassionate Transformation, and the ascension of Master Danyang, the Merciful-Wish Realized Man, into the rosy clouds. After the assembly of Daoist companions completed the purification feast, these lyrics were presented as a gift.

---

**Snow clears o’er fields and gardens,**
**Ice congeals on ponds and pools—**
**The time has come to delve into the depths of winter.**
On this day, Chongyang descended,
Revealing the true wind of the Dao.
Once more, Master Danyang,
Leaving the dusty world behind,
Soared to the celestial palace.
In the principle of the Mysterious Origin,
One ascends, one descends—
Manifesting the utmost divine power.

**Boundless—**
**The hands of the true master,**
From the capital’s south to Shaanxi’s west,
From Hebei to Shandong.
From children to the aged,
Who does not revere and honor?
Responding to things, adapting to circumstances,
Bestowing expedient means,
The Three Teachings harmonize as one.
All you gentlemen,
From this day forward,
When shall we meet again?

---

**To Wei Dechun**

The shackles of profit, the fetters of fame,
The ropes of affection, the cords of desire—
Who is not ensnared?
Yet if one can awaken,
It is but the fruition of prior causes.
How much worse to seek liberation in anguish,
Probing emotions only to turn them into enmity!
Do you not know?
In the unseen, true sages
Will guide you to grasp the Celestial Origin.

**Be steadfast,**
**Be vigilant—**
Rein in the mind-horse,
Capture the heart-ape.
Even a slight indulgence
Will damage the field of mushrooms.
In daily life, constantly examine your faults,
Among the multitude,
Never notice the transgressions of others.
Act thus,
And the original single point
Shall not lack perfection.

---

**To Liu Silang**

A family of cold simplicity,
A household of quiet leisure—
Who takes the trouble to seek it out?
The primal numinous awareness,
Imprisoned in the burning house.
Clinging to fleeting affections,
Never realizing the journey ahead has an end.
Awaken now!
Follow our kind,
Sever ten thousand entanglements at once.

**Carefree—**
What can compare?
The hawk freed from its cage,
The fish slipped from the hook.
Truly, drifting like a lone boat,
Cast off from its moorings.
Eat when hungry, drink when thirsty,
When sated, drum your belly and sing.
Unfettered,
When merit is complete, depart,
Striding high to visit Penglai.

---

**To Zhou Xin and Others**

Nobility and baseness are ordained by Heaven,
Flourishing and withering follow one’s lot—
Clearly, they do not lie in forced scheming.
What is gained was originally possessed,
What is lost was never truly there.
In vain, one employs cunning and luck,
Exhausting spirit and wit,
Wearing out the body.
Foolish and deluded souls,
Chasing the path of petty profit—
What do they gain from their greed?

**Moon and crow,**
**Hastening in flight—**
Within the span of a hundred years,
Light and shadow pass in an instant.
Once, rosy cheeks and raven locks
Turn entirely to frost and snow.
Soon, impermanence will arrive—
What will you rely on then?
How can you compare to me,
Empty, idle, and still,
Preserving the great elixir furnace?

---

**Again**

A single point of numinous clarity,
Ten thousand emotions tugging at the threads—
When has it ever known a moment’s peace?
The wheel of rebirth presses urgently,
Trading bones like mountains.
Thus, the deluded heart remains unenlightened,
Boasting of cleverness, galloping in cunning.
It is no different
From the moth flying into the flame,
The ant endlessly circling.

**This time,**
**Having personally encountered**
The descent of the host of immortals into the world,
Expounding and transforming among humankind,
They revealed the Great Teaching of Perfect Truth,
Pointing directly to the Mysterious Pass.
Abide always in constant purity, constant stillness,
Cease debating the reversal of aging and the return to youth.
From now on,
Dispel doubts, sever delusions,
And your name shall be listed among the ranks of immortals.

---

**Again**

The four karmic deeds, the three Peng spirits,
The seven emotions, the six desires—
Day and night, they incite and provoke.
Trapped in their cycles,
One cannot escape the black winds and waves.
Exhausting stinginess, greed, jealousy,
Cunning and deceit,
Endless snares are set.
Alas!
From ancient times to the present,
Who has not suffered their scorn?

**Brother Wang—**
**I have revealed the truth to you—**
You must be resolute and decisive,
Beware of wasting time.
Wield the sword of dispassionate wisdom,
Sharpen it again and again.
Even if you face the battlefield,
Strengthen your resolve,
Scatter the hordes of demons.
Upon your return,
The people will be at peace, the nation prosperous,
And all shall sing the song of Great Peace.

---

**On the Three Teachings**

Buddhism expounds emptiness and stillness,
Daoism discourses on purity and quietude,
Confucianism perfects the hundred virtues.
The three branches stand,
Mutually elucidating good affinities.
The Master, Confucius, is renowned as the Ultimate Sage,
The Tathāgata realized the Great Awakening as the Golden Immortal.
Our school’s patriarch,
Laozi, bears the august title—
Transmitted from ancient times to the present.

**Profound, profound—**
**Of one body,**
Who is high, who is low?
Who comes after, who comes first?
Together, they support the state,
Universally transforming humans and heavens.
Like the vast ocean,
Diverging into streams,
Flowing through all rivers.
Yet in the end,
Wherever they wander,
They all return to the source.

---

**In Reply to One Asking Why I Left Home and How to Cultivate the Dao**

Idle words scribbled,
Crude verses composed,
I roughly set forth my humble insights.
Ensnared in the dream of the world,
I idly passed twenty springs.
Suddenly awakening to the perilous road ahead,
Dragging along affections—
Who would dare to procrastinate?
I joined the Mystery Teaching,
Exploring its profound and wondrous secrets,
Freely delighting in the celestial truth.

**Embracing poverty—**
What a fine livelihood!
Returning to simplicity, nurturing purity,
Cultivating the spirit.
Fortunate to have the clear wind as companion,
The bright moon as neighbor.
I have claimed a life of leisure and freedom,
Following the sun and moon
As they rise in the east and set in the west.
In the realm beyond words,
A hint of the message—
How many can truly hear it?

---

**Instructions to the Assembly**

Fine sesame oil,
Double-sifted white flour,
Rice pounded and washed like ivory.
Meticulously prepared offerings,
A feast of rare delicacies arrayed.
Reverently performing the incense ritual, entering stillness,
Bowing repeatedly—
How could one shrink from toil?
We only hope that
The living may obtain blessings,
The deceased may ascend and transcend.

**All of you—**
Heed the exhortation:
Do not grow lax,
Hold fast to the Dao in unwavering devotion.
In clarity of mind and purification of thought,
Do not violate the celestial precepts.
Even the slightest breach of the fast or transgression of the precepts,
Without shame or remorse—
Not even a drop of water can atone.
Deficient in merit and conduct,
When the final reckoning comes,
Heaven and Earth will not lightly forgive.

---

**Lyrics Composed at the Command of Marshal Wanyan of Pingzhou for a Ritual Feast**

**Harmonious qi flows in warmth,**
the sun lingers, the breeze softens—
a radiant day where all things align.
Gardens and groves embroidered in splendor,
peach and plum in full bloom.
Swallows chatter, orioles vie in song,
golden-green willow fronds droop low.
A delicate fragrance drifts—
on this day, a celestial presence
bestows its auspicious grace upon the inner chambers.

**Divine countenance—**
how resplendent,
a visage of jade-like serenity,
a bearing faint as a crane’s.
In mind, humility and kindness,
in conduct, the great virtue ever upheld.
Longevity needs no repeated prayers,
for the true origin of nature
holds its own celestial destiny.
Sever the ties of the mundane,
awaken from the dream of the mortal world,
and return to feast at Jade Pool.

**Again—**
A stalwart talent in service of the realm,
a noble scion of the imperial house,
entrusted by imperial grace to guard Ping Mountain.
The land rests in peace—
what fortune to inspire joy!
The people are cherished as one’s own children,
laws tempered with mercy,
the foolish and stubborn shown compassion.
No partiality, no bias—
the renown of governance spreads,
resounding throughout the mortal realm.

**In leisure,**
ever accumulating virtue,
devoted to the teachings,
the heart preserved in tranquility.
Once more, honored with a summons,
a sacred altar is raised.
Through the ritual feast, the host of celestial sages is thanked,
as the azure-clad ones
open the gates of the unseen.
From this day forth,
the lofty immortals will bear witness,
and your name shall be inscribed
among the ranks of the transcendent.

*Wang Hai Chao*   *Self-Reflection*

Once, in years past, I was bound by craving and desire,
all my life’s deeds and doings—
now, in a single dawn, scattered like flying dust.
Knowing fate, I delight in Heaven’s decree,
before the wind, beneath the moon,
dwelling in seclusion by mountain and stream.
Silent as one struck dumb, like a fool,
heedless of others’ praise or blame.
All day long, no other task remains—
only to guard and preserve this little self.

Subtle and profound, the dark workings of the mysterious mechanism,
awakening to clarity, deep and still,
all merges into one refuge.
When the mood strikes, I sing and chant,
when joy arises, I dance and play,
following conditions, delighting in my emptiness and stillness.
No care for outward appearance,
freely indulging in carefree abandon,
at ease, without striving.
Content to pass my days in poverty and leisure,
letting the sun and moon race east and west.

*Jade Brazier: Three Streams of Snow* (Eleven Poems, originally titled *West River Moon*)
*In Response to Master Qin*

Leaning on my staff, I wander through water and clouds,
making my home wherever I go.
In grotto heavens, I recline to nurture cinnabar,
a thatched hut and wattle fence—fit for a painting.
Gathering yellow sprouts and white snow,
blending jade liquid and golden tea.
Of such sweet savor, no need for boasting—
it wins an immortal’s priceless prize.

*Hidden-Head Acrostic* (Four missing characters reconstructed as verse)

□ Greatness is not in firmness,
□ Now, deluded, clinging to home.
□ Yet awakening to purple spirit-sand,
□ Abandoning zither, chess, books, and paintings.
□ Years of diligent refinement,
□ Within, nurturing famed tea.
□ Now, knowing its flavor, why boast?
□ One day, merit perfected—priceless.

*Breaking the Four Characters*
*For Wang Houtang of Xianyi Temple*

Seeking the swiftest path to cultivation,
let not the horse lag nor the monkey run wild.
In every thing, sever all entanglements—
why ask of coiled serpents and tortoises?
Keep the spirit-terrace ever luminous,
naturally, the true breath will flow unbroken.
The immortal maiden within—fair of face—
is none other than your original countenance.

*For An Baozhen and Others*

Fish lost in the ford of suffering’s sea,
drifting with the waves, chasing the current.
Idly casting fragrant bait upon the hook,
in an instant, they turn their heads.
This, too, is the weight of past karma—
all things at once come to rest.
Where lies the path ahead?
Become a leader among the host of immortals.

*Again*

To transcend the sea of suffering,
first sever love and forget emotion.
From of old, level the pits and trenches,
lest you stray into desolate byways.
See through the illusions of fleeting splendor,
let no doubts or delusions arise.
With light and carefree steps, press onward—
each stride finds Penglai’s sure footing.

*Again*

Having awakened to the Way of home-leaving and Dao-seeking,
rely on a will unshakably firm.
Though myriad conditions stir in the heart,
all depends on diligent refinement.
Among the assembly, harbor no dissent,
put others’ benefit before your own.
Inner attainment and outer conduct—both perfected—
you shall attend the jade pool’s sacred feast.

*For Monk Liu of Puzhou Bodhisattva Hall*

The Great Dao makes no distinction of noble or base—
each and every person is already complete.
Let not the square inch of the heart spawn a thousand cares,
but keep every thought returning to purity and stillness.
Having grasped this message,
no need to bow the body or weary the form.
The spirit-terrace, brighter than the icy moon,
illumines the seeds of ignorance.

*Sighing for the Fire-and-Smoke Sons of Home-Leaving*

Some seek truth and yearn for the Dao—
pitiful, deserving of sighs.
Forsaking meat, abstaining from wine, shunning rank odors,
they take up the conduct of home-leaving.
In solitude, they close their eyes and knit their brows,
before others, they speak of the Dao and discourse on Chan.
Yet the slightest touch sets them ablaze—
all their former knowledge and insight, undone.

*Subtle Function*

No need to debate the public cases of ancients—
only present my own gate’s style.
At the third watch, the third stroke of the fast-breaking bell—
this is my family’s subtle function.
Limpid as empty flowers in form,
luminous as the moon in water’s reflection.
Two phases of this message—one in essence—
see how you might grasp and wield it.

*Double Extinction*

What words can speak of the ancestral Dao?
What discourse can touch the true lineage?
To move the lips and wag the tongue is already amiss—
it betrays the heart-seal of all immortals.
Thus, it is hard to expound,
yet I dare not refrain from a brief disclosure:
In every thing, the whole body is revealed—
in these words, I ask you to acknowledge it.

*In Gratitude for a Daoist Friend’s Visit*

Clumsy and weary of worldly profit,
indolent, I love only mountain dwelling.
Learning that a Daoist friend delights in calling,
I come to forge a bond of wondrous affinity.
I only wish to ascend the realm of longevity,
and further pray to deeply awaken to emptiness.
Laying down the toils of the dusty world, severing a myriad cares—
beyond the heights, where white clouds run deep.

*Golden Brazier: One Stream of Clouds* (Four Poems, originally titled *A Stretch of Clouds on Mount Wu*)
*For Sun Zhidao and Wang Juyi*

On purple paths, a traveler burdened by cares,
in red dust, a household bound by fame and profit.
All day long, vainly toiling—
no way to keep company with mist and clouds.
If you awaken to the brevity of this floating life,
Penglai’s immortal halls lie but a hand’s span away.
Hungry, eat; thirsty, drink; weary, sleep—
all else is without entanglement.

*Again*

Wind stilled, clouds first gathered,
tide level, waves at peace.
Idly wielding a light oar, clad in a straw cloak,
I angle near the riverbank.
The azure sky, so clear, like water—
how much more when the moon shines bright and the wind is gentle?
Alas, the fish and turtles refuse the hook—
I stand alone on the desolate isle of reeds.

*Parable of the Skull*

Day after day, lost in flowers and wine,
morning after morning, contending for power and wealth.
Suddenly, life ends, the grave is sealed—
on the outskirts, bleached bones lie exposed.
Though beaten with sticks and pounded with rods,
they are not as sharp and foolish as before.
I urge you to early awakening to this cause—
beyond the world, engage in true cultivation.

*Parable of the Puppet*

Faces painted in outlandish guise,
bodies swiftly assembled and joined.
Bowing and scraping, twisting and turning—so many postures,
yet all are but manipulated by others.
Of their own accord, they shake their heads and mimic shadows,
daily racing across the stage.
One day, the strings break, the pulling ceases—
only then do they awaken to the falsity of such causes.

*Little Layered Mountain*
*Expressing My Feelings*

With sudden awakening, I leap from the cage of worldly toil.
How many affairs fill the breast—all turn to emptiness.
Beyond the dust, I feign foolish simplicity in carefree ease.
Truly unshackled, truly free—
this is indeed the finest family tradition.

Opening the door to face the pine-clad peaks,
red dust cannot reach me here, deep in the white clouds.
The heart of Dao does not share the heart of profit.
I open my embrace,
reclining high to nurture indolent leisure.

*Six Golden Robust Cries of Jade Splendor*
*(Originally titled "Reduced-Word Magnolia Flower")*

*Exhorting Dao Companions*
The wondrous Dao of Perfect Truth:
first lay low the self and others.
The wondrous Dao perfects truth—
decisively gather essence, qi, and spirit.
When merit is complete and conduct fulfilled,
cast off the skin-sack without a care.
When conduct is fulfilled and merit complete,
pay homage before Master Danyang.

*Again*
Nonaction, purity, and stillness—
tiger coils and dragon twines, returning to great samādhi.
Purity, stillness, and nonaction:
mother and child harmonize, moving in and out together.
Carefree and at ease,
coming and going without entanglement.
At ease and carefree,
I leave it all to mountains and forests, or the marketplace.

*Again*
Not-human and human—
seeing through it all, it is but a trifling matter.
Human and not-human—
like spring wind blowing past the ear.
True merit, true conduct:
restrain the mind-horse and heart-ape within.
True conduct, true merit:
throughout the twelve hours, refine and refine the surging qi.

*For Dao Companion of Luo Family Manor*
Luo Manor, a realm unto itself,
winding waters encircle the mountains in mutual embrace.
Land lovely, people worthy,
revering the Dao, honoring truth, sowing seeds of good karma.
You invited me here,
offerings made with tireless devotion.
No way to repay such virtue—
only wishing each household flourishing longevity.

*For Master Hu*
Descendant of the Zi and Lin clans,
your discourse lofty, surpassing the crowd in distinction.
From birth, your bones were numinous, your flesh refined—
half your countenance already noble, emerging into the world with marvel.
You honor the Three Teachings,
revering the Buddha, the Sage, and walking the great Dao.
Silently nurturing the immortal embryo,
soon the white lotus will bloom amidst the flames.

*For Lady Wan Yan Ming Hui of Pengwei County*
The air is crisp and severe,
all things root deeply and secure their stems.
The *ming* leaves fully unfurl—
the immortal maiden moves her true self down from the jeweled terrace.
Pine’s bearing, crane’s form,
casting off burdens, purifying the heart, surpassing the crowd in distinction.
To celebrate her long life:
may fortune and longevity together attain the measure of Mustard Seed City.

*Eight "Treading Clouds" Songs*
*(Originally titled "Treading the Grass")*

*Self-Diversion*
Ren and Gui just ascended,
Bing and Ding already descended.

Watering and nurturing, the yellow sprout grows tall.
The numinous youth plucks it and ascends to the Jasper Palace,
where reed pipes and flutes welcome him with resonant song.
Tigers roar with auspicious winds,
dragons churn the snowy waves.
The turning of creation rests with the true master.
Refining cinnabar, the moonlight clears—
where the *Treading Clouds* dance, divine radiance gleams.

---

Pure and tranquil is the household’s way,
a livelihood of non-action.
Within lies a hidden truth.
In stillness and clarity, the profound mechanism is grasped;
in the boundless and indistinct, the subtle principle is known.
Atop the Seven Treasures Mountain,
within the Five Luminous Palaces,
freely savoring the nectar’s taste.
Sober yet drunk, drunk yet sober—
sober again, then drunk once more.

---

Worldly affairs swirl in chaos,
worldly passions stir in turmoil.
In spare moments, such thoughts are truly laughable.
When will the rise and fall of gain and loss cease?
When will the cycles of rise and ruin end?
Though present today,
who can guarantee tomorrow?
Listen well and recognize the Dao of non-action.
When cultivation and merit are both complete,
laughing, you’ll point to Penglai Isle amid the clouds.

*For Scholar Li of Anshan*
Enough of "alas" and "how"—
of "this" and "that."
Awakened, it’s best to cast them all aside.

Instructing the young and ignorant wastes the spirit,
lest habit and delay turn your hair to snow.
The years fly like arrows—
how can you bear to let them pass in vain?
I earnestly reveal the secrets of immortal cultivation:
if you’re willing to climb the cinnabar cassia branch,
you’ll share with me the moon of eternal life.

*For Liang the Scholar and his nephew of Luojia Village, who piously seek land to build an abbey*
Before Longling Peak,
behind Luojia Village—
mountains and rivers here are truly bright and fair.
If now you build a Daoist abbey,
in years to come it shall draw immortals to its halls.
I write these new verses
as modest praise and blessing.
Fortune and good omens have always followed virtue.
Uncle and nephew briefly forge a bond of action,
while their descendants shall enjoy boundless longevity.

*For the Assembly of Changchun Township at Chongdao Abbey*
The township bears the name "Eternal Spring,"
the abbey is called "Venerating the Dao."
Its hidden mysteries are hard for men to fathom.
Let not the radiance of Eternal Spring wither,
and with sincere hearts, turn the wheel of venerating the Dao.
Shut out the clamor,
delve within to seek the wondrous.
Ever hold fast to patience, humility, and modesty.
A wind of wisdom scatters the clouds atop the ridge,
and the moon of true nature shines with brilliant splendor.

*For Yang Deyuan*
His Daoist name is "Peaceful Leisure,"
his dharma name, "Virtue Distant."
Dharma name and Daoist name open the gate of expedience.
In peaceful leisure, let the nature roam free;
awakening to virtue’s distance, return to truth and goodness.
Outwardly appearing simple,
inwardly mastering cultivation.
Pressing on with effort, advancing the fire as in battle.
The golden crow flies toward Qujiang Pool,
the jade toad leaps from the Hall of Luminous Clarity.

For Yang Deyuan’s Request

The Dao is fundamentally wordless,
yet you press for words, demand explanations.
Poetry and song are but forced interpretations—
in its original state, the body abides in true constancy,
responding to circumstances without the slightest hindrance.
Moving freely in and out,
coming and going at ease,
before your eyes shines a radiant clarity.
If you dare accept this in an instant,
without shifting a single step, you transcend the Three Realms.

*Gazing Toward Penglai* (Three Poems, originally titled *Gazing at the River South*)

*For Elder Brother Zhongwu*

Often I laugh,
for delusion and awakening differ entirely.
Your livelihood is wealth and honor,
my life, quiet and carefree.
High pillowed, I recline amidst mist and clouds.

The joy of longevity,
how pure and fine its delight!
At leisure, I keep company with the thousand-year crane,
idly watching flowers that never fade through the four seasons.
Where might one find the home of immortals?

*For Magistrate Wang at Taolin Pass*

Scion of a noble lineage,
your pure reputation has long been heard.
By chance we met beyond the green peaks,
lingering together by Jade Spring’s edge,
our discourse in perfect accord with the true teaching.

Since parting,
we have met again without cause.
I fear your spiritual insight may be obscured by desire,
so I dare not refuse my clumsy, wild verses—
my intent entrusted to this brush and paper.

*For Scholar Zhang the Fourth*

O descendant of the Qing River,
hear the root of this matter:
in the past, you never found the raft to cross the shore,
and now you’ve entered the downhill years,
still bound by worldly attachments.

The realm of splendor,
illusory and unsteady.
Do not dream within a dream again,
nor seek the mysterious within the mysterious.
Mend the heavens within the cave.

*Three Poems on Freeing the Mind* (Originally titled *Nian Nu Jiao*)

*On Bamboo, Respectfully Following the Rhyme of Master Changchun*

A single stalk of bamboo,
possessing a natural standard,
towering and solitary.
Beyond the balustrade, before the window, its emerald shadows stretch—
its elegance far from the vulgar.
Within, its heart is hollow;
without, its integrity lofty,
surpassing all common trees.
In quiet recitation of wind and moon,
its resonance is like jade struck upon ice.

How lovable its pure essence and noble bearing,
drawing cranes to perch and phoenixes to nest,
through all seasons delighting the eye.
Its lush leaves, layer upon layer, gleam sleek and smooth,
its supple branches swaying, dense with green.
Its roots twist like dragons and serpents,
its qi infuses shoots and bamboo,
their flavor surpassing meat and grain.
This gentleman of refinement,
shares with me boundless good fortune.

*Double Ninth*

Mist and light, clear and verdant,
stirred by the west wind—
once more the Double Ninth arrives in leisure.
Red leaves and yellow blossoms alternate,
a scene truly worthy of painting.
In years past on this day,
silken robes and strings, feasts and golden cups flew.
Now, in retrospect,
all has become an empty dream.

Having entered the mysterious gate by good fortune,
worldly attachments of every kind
leave not the slightest trace.
A thatched hut, a brushwood fence, set one against the other—
pure and serene, ever refined.
All day, words forgotten;
through the night, sleepless,
I willingly endure this carefree life.
Who shares my aspiration?
Together we speak of the wordless truth.

*Lamenting the World*

The moon and sun hasten,
silently urging a man’s temples to silver.
All day he toils, yet remains unenlightened,
driven by the fires of family cares.
The empty fame of a snail’s horn,
the paltry profit of a fly’s head—
what good do they bring?
Hearing of health and strength,
best seek the living path among the clouds.

Sweeping my sleeves, I cast off worldly bonds,
by water’s edge, upon stone,
laughing freely as I compose idle verses.
A single grain of divine elixir gleams bright,
sparing me the entanglements of worldly dust.
Unfettered and at ease,
I wander where I will,
grasping the true message.
When merit is complete, I shall depart,
to dwell forever on Penglai’s immortal isle.

*Four Poems to the Tune of "Linjiang Xian"*

*Admonishing Debates Among Buddhists and Daoists*

Chan and Dao originally need no debate,
yet ancient sages forced them into names.
No need for those beyond the world to labor in vain—
each person has their portion,
everyone is perfectly complete.
Simply lay down the ten thousand entanglements,
and sever ignorance without hesitation.
In Jetavana’s garden, roam freely.
Where the mud ox roars,
midday strikes the third watch.

*For Shi Yu Xian and Others*

Bowing my head, I urge those on the same path to heed the teachings,
lest you waste the passing years.
Ever awaken and reflect, your Dao-heart steadfast.
Embrace others’ faults,
correct your own deviations.
In your true nature, there is no self or other—
in stillness, recognize the root source.
But deluded by false unions, you grasp at connections,
forever sinking in the sea of affliction,
unable to attain the Great Heavenly Net.

*Evening Scene*

As evening approaches, a gentle coolness stirs at door and window,
alone I sit on the pine-clad crag, chin in hand.
From on high, my gaze spans the horizon—
a solitary city veiled in mist and trees,

chunks.original_text: 草堂集 经名：草堂集。 金王丹挂撰。 一卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》太平部。 草堂集 五峰白云子王先生撰 词 满庭芳十一首 因腊月二十二日，乃重阳师祖悯化妙行真人降迹，丹阳师父顺化慈愿，真人升霞，众道友修斋毕，以词赠之。 雪霁郊园，冰凝池沼，时当探入穷冬。 重阳此日，降迹阐真风。 还是丹阳师父，辞尘世、飞上天宫。 玄元理，一升一降，显现至神功。 无穷。 真匠手，京南陕右，河北山东。 但儿童耆老，谁不钦崇。 应物随机顺化，垂方便、三教通同。 诸公等，从今已往，何日再相逢。 赠魏德纯 利锁名缰，恩绳爱索，兀谁不被牵缠。 但能省悟，早是具前缘。 那更苦求出离，情探处、翻作雠冤。 应知否，暗中真圣，接汝趁天元。 坚坚。 惟谨谨，收缚意马，擒捉心猿。 稍些儿放荡，损坏芝田。 日用常搜己过，居众中、莫见他愆。 如斯做，本来一点，不许不周圆。 赠刘四郎 冷淡家风，清闲门户，有谁着意搜求。 元初灵识，刚被火宅囚。 贪恋时间恩爱，终不道、前有程头。 当省悟，好学我辈，一割万缘休。 优游。 何可似，鹰离笼罩，鱼脱纶钩。 信飘飘浑如，解缆孤舟。 随分饥食渴饮，饱来后、鼓腹歌讴。 无萦绊，功成归去，高步访瀛洲。 赠周信等 贵贱由天，荣枯随分，分明不在强图。 得之本有，失者本来无。 谩使机关巧幸，劳神智、疲役形躯。 痴迷客，蝇头利路，贪得又何如。 蟾乌。 飞走急，百年限裹，光景须臾。 恰红颜青鬓，尽变霜须。 不日无常来到，问君待、着甚枝梧。 争如我，虚闲寂静，保固大丹炉。 又 一点灵明，万情牵绪，岂曾时暂宁闲。 轮回催逼，贩骨若丘山。 由是迷心未悟，夸聪辩、驰骋伶奸。 还同似，飞蛾投火，蝼蚁竞循环。 今番。 亲得遇，群仙降世，阐化人寰。 示全真大教，直指玄关。 常处常清常静，休持论、返老童颜。 从兹后，除疑断妄，名姓列仙班。 又 四业三彭，七情六欲，终宵永日教唆。 输他圈圆，难出黑风波。 起尽悭贪嫉妬，生机狡、无限张罗。 堪嗟处，从今至古，谁是不遭呵。 王哥。 亲说破，直须决烈，慎勿蹉跎。 把无情慧剑，每每频磨。 假使当场临阵，加刚锐、辟散群魔。 归来后，民安国富，齐唱太平歌。 咏三教 释演空寂，道谈清静，儒宗百行周全。 三枝既立，递互阐良缘。 尼父名扬至圣，如来证、大觉金仙。 吾门祖，老君睿号，今古自相传。 玄玄。 同一体，谁高谁下，谁后谁先。 共扶持邦国，普化人天。 浑似沧溟大海，分异派、流泛诸川。 然如是，周游去处，终久尽归源。 答人问缘甚出家如何修炼 闲写荒词，谩成拙句，略将管见铺陈。 贪迷世梦，虚度二十春。 忽悟前头路险，拖恩爱、孰敢因循。 投玄教，搜穷密妙，坦荡乐天真。 清贫。 活计好，还淳反朴，养素颐神。 幸清风作伴，明月为邻。 占得逍逼自在，从乌兔、东出西倾。 忘言处，些儿消息，能有几人闻。 示众 正清油，重罗白面，如牙细米舂淘。 精严办供，庖馔列珍肴。 虔恪行香点静，频作礼、岂惮劬劳。 惟求望，见存获福，亡者得升超。 吾曹。 听劝化，休生懈怠，道念坚牢。 在澄心涤虑，勿犯天条。 稍有违斋破戒，无惭愧、滴水难消。 亏功行，将来打算，天地不轻饶。 平州节使完颜骠骑命作醮索词

**The Thatched Hut Collection**
By Master Wang of Five Peaks and White Clouds

**Lyrics: Eleven "Court Full of Fragrance"**

Composed on the twenty-second day of the twelfth lunar month, the anniversary of the descent of the Venerable Ancestor Chongyang, the Wondrous-Act Realized Man of Compassionate Transformation, and the ascension of Master Danyang, the Merciful-Wish Realized Man, into the rosy clouds. After the assembly of Daoist companions completed the purification feast, these lyrics were presented as a gift.

---

**Snow clears o’er fields and gardens,**
**Ice congeals on ponds and pools—**
**The time has come to delve into the depths of winter.**
On this day, Chongyang descended,
Revealing the true wind of the Dao.
Once more, Master Danyang,
Leaving the dusty world behind,
Soared to the celestial palace.
In the principle of the Mysterious Origin,
One ascends, one descends—
Manifesting the utmost divine power.

**Boundless—**
**The hands of the true master,**
From the capital’s south to Shaanxi’s west,
From Hebei to Shandong.
From children to the aged,
Who does not revere and honor?
Responding to things, adapting to circumstances,
Bestowing expedient means,
The Three Teachings harmonize as one.
All you gentlemen,
From this day forward,
When shall we meet again?

---

**To Wei Dechun**

The shackles of profit, the fetters of fame,
The ropes of affection, the cords of desire—
Who is not ensnared?
Yet if one can awaken,
It is but the fruition of prior causes.
How much worse to seek liberation in anguish,
Probing emotions only to turn them into enmity!
Do you not know?
In the unseen, true sages
Will guide you to grasp the Celestial Origin.

**Be steadfast,**
**Be vigilant—**
Rein in the mind-horse,
Capture the heart-ape.
Even a slight indulgence
Will damage the field of mushrooms.
In daily life, constantly examine your faults,
Among the multitude,
Never notice the transgressions of others.
Act thus,
And the original single point
Shall not lack perfection.

---

**To Liu Silang**

A family of cold simplicity,
A household of quiet leisure—
Who takes the trouble to seek it out?
The primal numinous awareness,
Imprisoned in the burning house.
Clinging to fleeting affections,
Never realizing the journey ahead has an end.
Awaken now!
Follow our kind,
Sever ten thousand entanglements at once.

**Carefree—**
What can compare?
The hawk freed from its cage,
The fish slipped from the hook.
Truly, drifting like a lone boat,
Cast off from its moorings.
Eat when hungry, drink when thirsty,
When sated, drum your belly and sing.
Unfettered,
When merit is complete, depart,
Striding high to visit Penglai.

---

**To Zhou Xin and Others**

Nobility and baseness are ordained by Heaven,
Flourishing and withering follow one’s lot—
Clearly, they do not lie in forced scheming.
What is gained was originally possessed,
What is lost was never truly there.
In vain, one employs cunning and luck,
Exhausting spirit and wit,
Wearing out the body.
Foolish and deluded souls,
Chasing the path of petty profit—
What do they gain from their greed?

**Moon and crow,**
**Hastening in flight—**
Within the span of a hundred years,
Light and shadow pass in an instant.
Once, rosy cheeks and raven locks
Turn entirely to frost and snow.
Soon, impermanence will arrive—
What will you rely on then?
How can you compare to me,
Empty, idle, and still,
Preserving the great elixir furnace?

---

**Again**

A single point of numinous clarity,
Ten thousand emotions tugging at the threads—
When has it ever known a moment’s peace?
The wheel of rebirth presses urgently,
Trading bones like mountains.
Thus, the deluded heart remains unenlightened,
Boasting of cleverness, galloping in cunning.
It is no different
From the moth flying into the flame,
The ant endlessly circling.

**This time,**
**Having personally encountered**
The descent of the host of immortals into the world,
Expounding and transforming among humankind,
They revealed the Great Teaching of Perfect Truth,
Pointing directly to the Mysterious Pass.
Abide always in constant purity, constant stillness,
Cease debating the reversal of aging and the return to youth.
From now on,
Dispel doubts, sever delusions,
And your name shall be listed among the ranks of immortals.

---

**Again**

The four karmic deeds, the three Peng spirits,
The seven emotions, the six desires—
Day and night, they incite and provoke.
Trapped in their cycles,
One cannot escape the black winds and waves.
Exhausting stinginess, greed, jealousy,
Cunning and deceit,
Endless snares are set.
Alas!
From ancient times to the present,
Who has not suffered their scorn?

**Brother Wang—**
**I have revealed the truth to you—**
You must be resolute and decisive,
Beware of wasting time.
Wield the sword of dispassionate wisdom,
Sharpen it again and again.
Even if you face the battlefield,
Strengthen your resolve,
Scatter the hordes of demons.
Upon your return,
The people will be at peace, the nation prosperous,
And all shall sing the song of Great Peace.

---

**On the Three Teachings**

Buddhism expounds emptiness and stillness,
Daoism discourses on purity and quietude,
Confucianism perfects the hundred virtues.
The three branches stand,
Mutually elucidating good affinities.
The Master, Confucius, is renowned as the Ultimate Sage,
The Tathāgata realized the Great Awakening as the Golden Immortal.
Our school’s patriarch,
Laozi, bears the august title—
Transmitted from ancient times to the present.

**Profound, profound—**
**Of one body,**
Who is high, who is low?
Who comes after, who comes first?
Together, they support the state,
Universally transforming humans and heavens.
Like the vast ocean,
Diverging into streams,
Flowing through all rivers.
Yet in the end,
Wherever they wander,
They all return to the source.

---

**In Reply to One Asking Why I Left Home and How to Cultivate the Dao**

Idle words scribbled,
Crude verses composed,
I roughly set forth my humble insights.
Ensnared in the dream of the world,
I idly passed twenty springs.
Suddenly awakening to the perilous road ahead,
Dragging along affections—
Who would dare to procrastinate?
I joined the Mystery Teaching,
Exploring its profound and wondrous secrets,
Freely delighting in the celestial truth.

**Embracing poverty—**
What a fine livelihood!
Returning to simplicity, nurturing purity,
Cultivating the spirit.
Fortunate to have the clear wind as companion,
The bright moon as neighbor.
I have claimed a life of leisure and freedom,
Following the sun and moon
As they rise in the east and set in the west.
In the realm beyond words,
A hint of the message—
How many can truly hear it?

---

**Instructions to the Assembly**

Fine sesame oil,
Double-sifted white flour,
Rice pounded and washed like ivory.
Meticulously prepared offerings,
A feast of rare delicacies arrayed.
Reverently performing the incense ritual, entering stillness,
Bowing repeatedly—
How could one shrink from toil?
We only hope that
The living may obtain blessings,
The deceased may ascend and transcend.

**All of you—**
Heed the exhortation:
Do not grow lax,
Hold fast to the Dao in unwavering devotion.
In clarity of mind and purification of thought,
Do not violate the celestial precepts.
Even the slightest breach of the fast or transgression of the precepts,
Without shame or remorse—
Not even a drop of water can atone.
Deficient in merit and conduct,
When the final reckoning comes,
Heaven and Earth will not lightly forgive.

---

**Lyrics Composed at the Command of Marshal Wanyan of Pingzhou for a Ritual Feast**

**Harmonious qi flows in warmth,**
the sun lingers, the breeze softens—
a radiant day where all things align.
Gardens and groves embroidered in splendor,
peach and plum in full bloom.
Swallows chatter, orioles vie in song,
golden-green willow fronds droop low.
A delicate fragrance drifts—
on this day, a celestial presence
bestows its auspicious grace upon the inner chambers.

**Divine countenance—**
how resplendent,
a visage of jade-like serenity,
a bearing faint as a crane’s.
In mind, humility and kindness,
in conduct, the great virtue ever upheld.
Longevity needs no repeated prayers,
for the true origin of nature
holds its own celestial destiny.
Sever the ties of the mundane,
awaken from the dream of the mortal world,
and return to feast at Jade Pool.

**Again—**
A stalwart talent in service of the realm,
a noble scion of the imperial house,
entrusted by imperial grace to guard Ping Mountain.
The land rests in peace—
what fortune to inspire joy!
The people are cherished as one’s own children,
laws tempered with mercy,
the foolish and stubborn shown compassion.
No partiality, no bias—
the renown of governance spreads,
resounding throughout the mortal realm.

**In leisure,**
ever accumulating virtue,
devoted to the teachings,
the heart preserved in tranquility.
Once more, honored with a summons,
a sacred altar is raised.
Through the ritual feast, the host of celestial sages is thanked,
as the azure-clad ones
open the gates of the unseen.
From this day forth,
the lofty immortals will bear witness,
and your name shall be inscribed
among the ranks of the transcendent.

*Wang Hai Chao*   *Self-Reflection*

Once, in years past, I was bound by craving and desire,
all my life’s deeds and doings—
now, in a single dawn, scattered like flying dust.
Knowing fate, I delight in Heaven’s decree,
before the wind, beneath the moon,
dwelling in seclusion by mountain and stream.
Silent as one struck dumb, like a fool,
heedless of others’ praise or blame.
All day long, no other task remains—
only to guard and preserve this little self.

Subtle and profound, the dark workings of the mysterious mechanism,
awakening to clarity, deep and still,
all merges into one refuge.
When the mood strikes, I sing and chant,
when joy arises, I dance and play,
following conditions, delighting in my emptiness and stillness.
No care for outward appearance,
freely indulging in carefree abandon,
at ease, without striving.
Content to pass my days in poverty and leisure,
letting the sun and moon race east and west.

*Jade Brazier: Three Streams of Snow* (Eleven Poems, originally titled *West River Moon*)
*In Response to Master Qin*

Leaning on my staff, I wander through water and clouds,
making my home wherever I go.
In grotto heavens, I recline to nurture cinnabar,
a thatched hut and wattle fence—fit for a painting.
Gathering yellow sprouts and white snow,
blending jade liquid and golden tea.
Of such sweet savor, no need for boasting—
it wins an immortal’s priceless prize.

*Hidden-Head Acrostic* (Four missing characters reconstructed as verse)

□ Greatness is not in firmness,
□ Now, deluded, clinging to home.
□ Yet awakening to purple spirit-sand,
□ Abandoning zither, chess, books, and paintings.
□ Years of diligent refinement,
□ Within, nurturing famed tea.
□ Now, knowing its flavor, why boast?
□ One day, merit perfected—priceless.

*Breaking the Four Characters*
*For Wang Houtang of Xianyi Temple*

Seeking the swiftest path to cultivation,
let not the horse lag nor the monkey run wild.
In every thing, sever all entanglements—
why ask of coiled serpents and tortoises?
Keep the spirit-terrace ever luminous,
naturally, the true breath will flow unbroken.
The immortal maiden within—fair of face—
is none other than your original countenance.

*For An Baozhen and Others*

Fish lost in the ford of suffering’s sea,
drifting with the waves, chasing the current.
Idly casting fragrant bait upon the hook,
in an instant, they turn their heads.
This, too, is the weight of past karma—
all things at once come to rest.
Where lies the path ahead?
Become a leader among the host of immortals.

*Again*

To transcend the sea of suffering,
first sever love and forget emotion.
From of old, level the pits and trenches,
lest you stray into desolate byways.
See through the illusions of fleeting splendor,
let no doubts or delusions arise.
With light and carefree steps, press onward—
each stride finds Penglai’s sure footing.

*Again*

Having awakened to the Way of home-leaving and Dao-seeking,
rely on a will unshakably firm.
Though myriad conditions stir in the heart,
all depends on diligent refinement.
Among the assembly, harbor no dissent,
put others’ benefit before your own.
Inner attainment and outer conduct—both perfected—
you shall attend the jade pool’s sacred feast.

*For Monk Liu of Puzhou Bodhisattva Hall*

The Great Dao makes no distinction of noble or base—
each and every person is already complete.
Let not the square inch of the heart spawn a thousand cares,
but keep every thought returning to purity and stillness.
Having grasped this message,
no need to bow the body or weary the form.
The spirit-terrace, brighter than the icy moon,
illumines the seeds of ignorance.

*Sighing for the Fire-and-Smoke Sons of Home-Leaving*

Some seek truth and yearn for the Dao—
pitiful, deserving of sighs.
Forsaking meat, abstaining from wine, shunning rank odors,
they take up the conduct of home-leaving.
In solitude, they close their eyes and knit their brows,
before others, they speak of the Dao and discourse on Chan.
Yet the slightest touch sets them ablaze—
all their former knowledge and insight, undone.

*Subtle Function*

No need to debate the public cases of ancients—
only present my own gate’s style.
At the third watch, the third stroke of the fast-breaking bell—
this is my family’s subtle function.
Limpid as empty flowers in form,
luminous as the moon in water’s reflection.
Two phases of this message—one in essence—
see how you might grasp and wield it.

*Double Extinction*

What words can speak of the ancestral Dao?
What discourse can touch the true lineage?
To move the lips and wag the tongue is already amiss—
it betrays the heart-seal of all immortals.
Thus, it is hard to expound,
yet I dare not refrain from a brief disclosure:
In every thing, the whole body is revealed—
in these words, I ask you to acknowledge it.

*In Gratitude for a Daoist Friend’s Visit*

Clumsy and weary of worldly profit,
indolent, I love only mountain dwelling.
Learning that a Daoist friend delights in calling,
I come to forge a bond of wondrous affinity.
I only wish to ascend the realm of longevity,
and further pray to deeply awaken to emptiness.
Laying down the toils of the dusty world, severing a myriad cares—
beyond the heights, where white clouds run deep.

*Golden Brazier: One Stream of Clouds* (Four Poems, originally titled *A Stretch of Clouds on Mount Wu*)
*For Sun Zhidao and Wang Juyi*

On purple paths, a traveler burdened by cares,
in red dust, a household bound by fame and profit.
All day long, vainly toiling—
no way to keep company with mist and clouds.
If you awaken to the brevity of this floating life,
Penglai’s immortal halls lie but a hand’s span away.
Hungry, eat; thirsty, drink; weary, sleep—
all else is without entanglement.

*Again*

Wind stilled, clouds first gathered,
tide level, waves at peace.
Idly wielding a light oar, clad in a straw cloak,
I angle near the riverbank.
The azure sky, so clear, like water—
how much more when the moon shines bright and the wind is gentle?
Alas, the fish and turtles refuse the hook—
I stand alone on the desolate isle of reeds.

*Parable of the Skull*

Day after day, lost in flowers and wine,
morning after morning, contending for power and wealth.
Suddenly, life ends, the grave is sealed—
on the outskirts, bleached bones lie exposed.
Though beaten with sticks and pounded with rods,
they are not as sharp and foolish as before.
I urge you to early awakening to this cause—
beyond the world, engage in true cultivation.

*Parable of the Puppet*

Faces painted in outlandish guise,
bodies swiftly assembled and joined.
Bowing and scraping, twisting and turning—so many postures,
yet all are but manipulated by others.
Of their own accord, they shake their heads and mimic shadows,
daily racing across the stage.
One day, the strings break, the pulling ceases—
only then do they awaken to the falsity of such causes.

*Little Layered Mountain*
*Expressing My Feelings*

chunks.translated_text:
With sudden awakening, I leap from the cage of worldly toil.
How many affairs fill the breast—all turn to emptiness.
Beyond the dust, I feign foolish simplicity in carefree ease.
Truly unshackled, truly free—
this is indeed the finest family tradition.

Opening the door to face the pine-clad peaks,
red dust cannot reach me here, deep in the white clouds.
The heart of Dao does not share the heart of profit.
I open my embrace,
reclining high to nurture indolent leisure.

*Six Golden Robust Cries of Jade Splendor*
*(Originally titled "Reduced-Word Magnolia Flower")*

*Exhorting Dao Companions*
The wondrous Dao of Perfect Truth:
first lay low the self and others.
The wondrous Dao perfects truth—
decisively gather essence, qi, and spirit.
When merit is complete and conduct fulfilled,
cast off the skin-sack without a care.
When conduct is fulfilled and merit complete,
pay homage before Master Danyang.

*Again*
Nonaction, purity, and stillness—
tiger coils and dragon twines, returning to great samādhi.
Purity, stillness, and nonaction:
mother and child harmonize, moving in and out together.
Carefree and at ease,
coming and going without entanglement.
At ease and carefree,
I leave it all to mountains and forests, or the marketplace.

*Again*
Not-human and human—
seeing through it all, it is but a trifling matter.
Human and not-human—
like spring wind blowing past the ear.
True merit, true conduct:
restrain the mind-horse and heart-ape within.
True conduct, true merit:
throughout the twelve hours, refine and refine the surging qi.

*For Dao Companion of Luo Family Manor*
Luo Manor, a realm unto itself,
winding waters encircle the mountains in mutual embrace.
Land lovely, people worthy,
revering the Dao, honoring truth, sowing seeds of good karma.
You invited me here,
offerings made with tireless devotion.
No way to repay such virtue—
only wishing each household flourishing longevity.

*For Master Hu*
Descendant of the Zi and Lin clans,
your discourse lofty, surpassing the crowd in distinction.
From birth, your bones were numinous, your flesh refined—
half your countenance already noble, emerging into the world with marvel.
You honor the Three Teachings,
revering the Buddha, the Sage, and walking the great Dao.
Silently nurturing the immortal embryo,
soon the white lotus will bloom amidst the flames.

*For Lady Wan Yan Ming Hui of Pengwei County*
The air is crisp and severe,
all things root deeply and secure their stems.
The *ming* leaves fully unfurl—
the immortal maiden moves her true self down from the jeweled terrace.

casting off burdens, purifying the heart, surpassing the crowd in distinction.

Watering and nurturing, the yellow sprout grows tall.
The numinous youth plucks it and ascends to the Jasper Palace,
where reed pipes and flutes welcome him with resonant song.
Tigers roar with auspicious winds,
dragons churn the snowy waves.
The turning of creation rests with the true master.
Refining cinnabar, the moonlight clears—
where the *Treading Clouds* dance, divine radiance gleams.

---

Pure and tranquil is the household’s way,
a livelihood of non-action.
Within lies a hidden truth.
In stillness and clarity, the profound mechanism is grasped;
in the boundless and indistinct, the subtle principle is known.
Atop the Seven Treasures Mountain,
within the Five Luminous Palaces,
freely savoring the nectar’s taste.
Sober yet drunk, drunk yet sober—
sober again, then drunk once more.

---

Worldly affairs swirl in chaos,
worldly passions stir in turmoil.
In spare moments, such thoughts are truly laughable.
When will the rise and fall of gain and loss cease?
When will the cycles of rise and ruin end?
Though present today,
who can guarantee tomorrow?
Listen well and recognize the Dao of non-action.
When cultivation and merit are both complete,
laughing, you’ll point to Penglai Isle amid the clouds.

Enough of "alas" and "how"—
of "this" and "that."
Awakened, it’s best to cast them all aside.

Instructing the young and ignorant wastes the spirit,
lest habit and delay turn your hair to snow.
The years fly like arrows—
how can you bear to let them pass in vain?
I earnestly reveal the secrets of immortal cultivation:
if you’re willing to climb the cinnabar cassia branch,
you’ll share with me the moon of eternal life.

*For Liang the Scholar and his nephew of Luojia Village, who piously seek land to build an abbey*
Before Longling Peak,
behind Luojia Village—
mountains and rivers here are truly bright and fair.
If now you build a Daoist abbey,
in years to come it shall draw immortals to its halls.
I write these new verses
as modest praise and blessing.
Fortune and good omens have always followed virtue.
Uncle and nephew briefly forge a bond of action,
while their descendants shall enjoy boundless longevity.

*For the Assembly of Changchun Township at Chongdao Abbey*
The township bears the name "Eternal Spring,"
the abbey is called "Venerating the Dao."
Its hidden mysteries are hard for men to fathom.
Let not the radiance of Eternal Spring wither,
and with sincere hearts, turn the wheel of venerating the Dao.
Shut out the clamor,
delve within to seek the wondrous.
Ever hold fast to patience, humility, and modesty.
A wind of wisdom scatters the clouds atop the ridge,

chunks.translated_text:
For Yang Deyuan’s Request

The Dao is fundamentally wordless,
yet you press for words, demand explanations.
Poetry and song are but forced interpretations—
in its original state, the body abides in true constancy,
responding to circumstances without the slightest hindrance.
Moving freely in and out,
coming and going at ease,
before your eyes shines a radiant clarity.
If you dare accept this in an instant,
without shifting a single step, you transcend the Three Realms.

*Gazing Toward Penglai* (Three Poems, originally titled *Gazing at the River South*)

*For Elder Brother Zhongwu*

Often I laugh,
for delusion and awakening differ entirely.
Your livelihood is wealth and honor,
my life, quiet and carefree.
High pillowed, I recline amidst mist and clouds.

The joy of longevity,
how pure and fine its delight!
At leisure, I keep company with the thousand-year crane,
idly watching flowers that never fade through the four seasons.
Where might one find the home of immortals?

*For Magistrate Wang at Taolin Pass*

Scion of a noble lineage,
your pure reputation has long been heard.
By chance we met beyond the green peaks,
lingering together by Jade Spring’s edge,
our discourse in perfect accord with the true teaching.

Since parting,
we have met again without cause.
I fear your spiritual insight may be obscured by desire,
so I dare not refuse my clumsy, wild verses—
my intent entrusted to this brush and paper.

*For Scholar Zhang the Fourth*

O descendant of the Qing River,
hear the root of this matter:
in the past, you never found the raft to cross the shore,
and now you’ve entered the downhill years,
still bound by worldly attachments.

The realm of splendor,
illusory and unsteady.
Do not dream within a dream again,
nor seek the mysterious within the mysterious.
Mend the heavens within the cave.

*Three Poems on Freeing the Mind* (Originally titled *Nian Nu Jiao*)

*On Bamboo, Respectfully Following the Rhyme of Master Changchun*

A single stalk of bamboo,
possessing a natural standard,
towering and solitary.
Beyond the balustrade, before the window, its emerald shadows stretch—
its elegance far from the vulgar.
Within, its heart is hollow;
without, its integrity lofty,
surpassing all common trees.
In quiet recitation of wind and moon,
its resonance is like jade struck upon ice.

How lovable its pure essence and noble bearing,
drawing cranes to perch and phoenixes to nest,
through all seasons delighting the eye.
Its lush leaves, layer upon layer, gleam sleek and smooth,
its supple branches swaying, dense with green.
Its roots twist like dragons and serpents,
its qi infuses shoots and bamboo,
their flavor surpassing meat and grain.
This gentleman of refinement,
shares with me boundless good fortune.

*Double Ninth*

Mist and light, clear and verdant,
stirred by the west wind—
once more the Double Ninth arrives in leisure.
Red leaves and yellow blossoms alternate,
a scene truly worthy of painting.
In years past on this day,
silken robes and strings, feasts and golden cups flew.
Now, in retrospect,
all has become an empty dream.

Having entered the mysterious gate by good fortune,
worldly attachments of every kind
leave not the slightest trace.
A thatched hut, a brushwood fence, set one against the other—
pure and serene, ever refined.
All day, words forgotten;
through the night, sleepless,
I willingly endure this carefree life.
Who shares my aspiration?
Together we speak of the wordless truth.

*Lamenting the World*

The moon and sun hasten,
silently urging a man’s temples to silver.
All day he toils, yet remains unenlightened,
driven by the fires of family cares.
The empty fame of a snail’s horn,
the paltry profit of a fly’s head—
what good do they bring?
Hearing of health and strength,
best seek the living path among the clouds.

Sweeping my sleeves, I cast off worldly bonds,
by water’s edge, upon stone,
laughing freely as I compose idle verses.
A single grain of divine elixir gleams bright,
sparing me the entanglements of worldly dust.
Unfettered and at ease,
I wander where I will,
grasping the true message.
When merit is complete, I shall depart,
to dwell forever on Penglai’s immortal isle.

*Four Poems to the Tune of "Linjiang Xian"*

*Admonishing Debates Among Buddhists and Daoists*

Chan and Dao originally need no debate,
yet ancient sages forced them into names.
No need for those beyond the world to labor in vain—
each person has their portion,
everyone is perfectly complete.
Simply lay down the ten thousand entanglements,
and sever ignorance without hesitation.
In Jetavana’s garden, roam freely.
Where the mud ox roars,
midday strikes the third watch.

*For Shi Yu Xian and Others*

Bowing my head, I urge those on the same path to heed the teachings,
lest you waste the passing years.
Ever awaken and reflect, your Dao-heart steadfast.
Embrace others’ faults,
correct your own deviations.
In your true nature, there is no self or other—
in stillness, recognize the root source.
But deluded by false unions, you grasp at connections,
forever sinking in the sea of affliction,
unable to attain the Great Heavenly Net.

*Evening Scene*

As evening approaches, a gentle coolness stirs at door and window,
alone I sit on the pine-clad crag, chin in hand.
From on high, my gaze spans the horizon—
a solitary city veiled in mist and trees,
a distant shore where a single sail returns.
For ten thousand miles, the azure sky is clear as water,
clouds idle, unmoving in the slightest.
Bright and luminous, they play in the radiant sunlight.
A perfect light embraces the dharma realm,
its splendor shining upon the Jade Pool.

*Playfully Composed Upon Hearing the Cuckoo*

A mind at leisure grows weary of idleness,
carefree and unconcerned, I forget all schemes.
At dawn, a light rain passes the window.
Emerald mists enfold the green peaks—
again, I hear the cuckoo’s cry.
Each call rings clear: "Better to go home!"
Now my time to return has come.
When merit is complete, I shall step upon the clouds.
Why trouble with clever arguments,
vainly urging one another on?

*Guest at the Blue Lotus Pond* (Originally titled *Green Jade Case*)

*For Wu Lin Da Derun*

Now that you have awakened to the suffering of worldly toil,
your body has already met its fate.
Cast aside vanity, embrace simplicity.
Ever hold fast to gentleness and humility,
never give rise to greed or envy—
let your words and deeds match.
In stillness, do not stir idle thoughts,
and you will grasp the wondrous mystery of leisure.
Nurture the Three Fields without cease,
day or night.
Yin recedes, yang grows,
qi congeals, the elixir forms—
only then may you be called a companion of the Perfect Truth.

*Two Poems from "Immortal of Yellow Crane Cave"* (Originally titled *Bu Suan Zi*)

*For the Assembly*

I urge those who cultivate immortality:
each must remain patient and enduring.
Through ten thousand hardships and a thousand demons,
let your resolve grow stronger—
never alter your initial resolve.
Like the full moon’s light,
radiant and serene beyond the vast sky,
turning without partiality to fill the great thousand worlds,
trust that the floating clouds will disperse.

*For Cheng the Third*

A man is like a candle in the wind—
who would turn their heart to look back?
Worldly ties bind tightly,
how could one not feel the suffering?
Fortunately, there is the path of immortal cultivation,
to be pursued in leisure and ease.
Wherever you go, roam freely—
when merit is complete, dwell in Penglai and Yingzhou.

*Two Poems to the Tune of "Zhe Ying Jiao"*

*For Yang Deyuan*
His Daoist name is "Peaceful Leisure,"
his dharma name, "Virtue Distant."
Dharma name and Daoist name open the gate of expedience.
In peaceful leisure, let the nature roam free;
awakening to virtue’s distance, return to truth and goodness.

chunks.original_text: 山居述怀 泉石清幽，好个真游地。 香风散、彩云呈瑞。 日暖天和，更时有珍禽戏。 嘉致。 总妆点、山家况味。 外景充盈，内景还相契。 丹炉畔、虎龙交会。 女姹婴娇，频劝我、倾金液。 沈醉。 但高卧、晴霞影裹。 赠油频王广道 广道王三，天赋精诚艺。 将油面、和调运制。 应物番番，但做造由心意。 依理。 炼在、长生炉内。 按候知时，拈出真奇异。 光明灿、馨香馥鼻。 试与尝来，又别是、甘甜味。 妙矣。 堪献入、仙家筵会。 喜迁莺 赠康德机 宿缘深重。 早省悟，浮生都如一梦。 壮志回头，专心入道，尘事豁然驱屏。 要脱死生轮转，认取元来本柄。 甚为准。 待与君说破，些儿捷径。 日用。 持清静。 积累内功，外行心平等。 次泯贪嗔，调和神气，休放马猿驰骋。 万里黑云消散，一点灵明光莹。 仙路稳。 这回须免了，改头换影。 忆王孙八首 自咏
chunks.translated_text:
**Reflections on Mountain Dwelling**

Pure and secluded, the springs and rocks—
a fine place for true wandering.
Fragrant winds scatter,
auspicious clouds appear.
Warm sun, harmonious sky,
rare birds at play from time to time.
How delightful—
all adorn the mountain dweller’s life.

Outer scenes abound,
inner scenes still harmonize.
By the elixir furnace,
tiger and dragon unite.
Fair maiden and youthful lad
often urge me to pour the golden liquid.
Deeply intoxicated,
I lie at ease amid the radiant clouds.

---

**To Wang Guangdao, the Oil Refiner**

Wang Guangdao,
heaven-endowed with skill and sincerity.
Kneading oil and flour,
shaping and refining with care.
Responding to things again and again,
each creation follows the heart’s intent.
True to principle—
tempered within the furnace of immortality.

Timing known, seasons observed,
he draws forth wondrous marvels.
Brilliant and bright,
fragrant to the nose.
Come, taste it—
another kind of sweetness.
How wondrous!
Worthy to offer at the immortals’ feast.

---

**To the Tune "Joyous Oriole Ascending"**
*For Kang Deji*

Deep karmic roots.
Early awakened—
this floating life is but a dream.
Turning from youthful ambition,
devoting the heart to the Dao,
worldly affairs cast aside like screens.
To escape the wheel of death and rebirth,
recognize the original handle.
What is the standard?
I shall reveal to you
a swift and sure path.

In daily practice,
maintain clarity and stillness.
Cultivate inner power,
outward conduct in equanimity.
Next, dissolve greed and wrath,
harmonize spirit and qi,
never let the horse and monkey run wild.
A thousand miles of dark clouds disperse—
a single point of numinous light shines.
The immortal’s path is steady.
This time, you must escape
the cycle of rebirth and transformation.

---

*Self-Reflection*

chunks.original_text: 云何便会做痴憨，只为番番世事谙。 度日随缘不外贪。 处云庵。 渴饮醍醐味转甘。 又 逍遥坦荡绝忧愁，管甚流年春复秋。 露地安眠放白牛。 晚烟收。 一曲高歌古渡头。 又 不持斋戒不看经，不论金丹共五行。 玉瑟闲调月正明。 韵轻清。 响彻瑶台十二层。 又 三田常用铁牛耕，种得黄芽渐渐生。 法雨时时浇灌频。 转滋荣。 采摘归来上玉京。 又 几人学得我风流，疏尽尘缘散尽愁。 闲品羌笛驾白牛。 好因由。 四大神舟任意游。 又 本来真性唤神仙，为爱幽栖远市廛。 独隐山堂妙最玄。 乐恬然。 欣即高歌困即眠。 又 四时流转急如梭，百岁韶华屈指过。 惟愿人人出爱河。 养冲和。 功满超升赴大罗。 因王孙二旧友同日不期而会 闲闲闲裹忆王孙，今幸相逢语笑频。 各各勤修精气神。 行功臻，同宴桃源碧洞春。 好离乡四首　本名南乡子 警世人本是神仙，只为当初纵马猿。 换骨更形无定止， 连绵。 致使尘情种种牵。
chunks.translated_text:
**How does one become a fool?**
Only from knowing worldly affairs too well.
Passing days with fate, no greed beyond.
Dwelling in Cloud Hermitage—
thirst quenched with *tīrtha*, the taste grows sweet.

---

**Carefree and vast, free from sorrow,**
what care for flowing springs and returning autumns?
Sleeping sound in the open, the white ox set loose.
Evening mist gathers—
a single song at the ancient ferry’s head.

---

**No fasting, no precepts, no scriptures read,**
no talk of golden elixirs or the Five Phases.
Idly tuning the jade zither beneath the bright moon,
notes light and pure—
resounding through the twelve tiers of Jade Terrace.

---

**The Three Fields plowed ever by iron ox,**
planting yellow sprouts that slowly grow.
Dharma rain waters them ceaselessly,
turning lush and flourishing—
harvested and borne to Jade Capital.

---

**How many have learned my ease?**
All worldly ties severed, all cares dissolved.
Leisurely playing the Qiang flute, riding the white ox—
what fine cause!
The four great spirit-boats drift as they will.

---

**The true nature itself is called immortal—**
for love of seclusion, far from the marketplace.
Alone in the mountain hall, mystery most profound.
Joy in tranquility—
happy, I sing; weary, I sleep.

---

**The four seasons turn swift as a shuttle,**
a hundred years of splendor pass at a finger’s count.
Only wishing all may escape the river of desire,
nurturing harmony—
when merit is full, ascend to the Great Canopy.

---

**For Two Old Friends, Wangsun and Another, Who Met Unexpectedly on the Same Day**

Leisurely, leisurely recalling Prince Wang,
today by fortune we meet, words and laughter frequent.
Each diligently refining essence, qi, and spirit—
practice perfected,
together feasting in Peach Spring’s jade-green cavern.

---

**Four Poems to the Tune "Leaving Home" (Originally "Southern Home")**
**Admonishing the World**

Men are by nature immortals—
only for letting horse and monkey run wild at first.
Bone changed, form altered without cease,
endlessly—
binding them to dust and passion in all its forms.

chunks.original_text: 若解固根原，玉鼎金炉聚汞铅。 炼三千功行满，还元。 复返蓬瀛绝变迁。 〔雪夜〕 余隐居昆仑山清神洞，常习不睡，因久坐，不觉雪降。 其夜稍暖，岩溜半溶，似乎有声。 俄然而起，出户视之，四围山色尽为更变，因倚松而作是词。 坐久欲眬睛，不觉天公祥瑞呈。 夜暖忽闻岩溜滴，声声。 唤觉游仙梦不成。 级履起开扃，四望遥峰尽变更。 唯有长松天性异，坚贞。 独倚幽岩显道清。 〔寄族人〕 余祖居利州，有李仙者自彼而来，言族中亲春闻先生入道多岁矣，未知是王家那一宗派，请示一书。 因成此词以寄之。 聊与话行藏，生死轮回岂尽量。
chunks.translated_text:
**If one grasps how to secure the root and origin,**
in jade crucible and golden furnace mercury and lead converge.
Refining three thousand merits, when practice is full,
return to the source—
reascend Penglai and Yingzhou, beyond all change and decay.

**[Snowy Night]**
I dwell in seclusion in Clear Spirit Grotto on Kunlun Mountain,
often practicing sleeplessness. After long sitting,
I did not notice the snowfall.
That night grew slightly warm; half-melted icicles from the cliffs
seemed to make a sound.
Suddenly rising, I stepped outside to look—
the mountains on all sides had transformed entirely.
Leaning against a pine, I composed this lyric.

Sitting long, my eyes grew heavy with drowsiness,
unaware the heavens displayed their auspicious signs.
The night warmed, and I suddenly heard the dripping of cliff icicles,
drop by drop—
awakening, my dream of wandering immortals could not take form.

I rose, climbing the steps to open the latch,
gazing afar—all distant peaks had changed.
Only the tall pines, of nature distinct,
stood steadfast.
Alone, I leaned against the secluded crag, the Dao’s clarity revealed.

**[To a Clan Member]**
My ancestral home lies in Lizhou. A certain Immortal Li
came from there, saying that among my kin in springtime,
they heard I had entered the Dao many years ago.
They know not which branch of the Wang family I belong to—
I was asked to send word.
Thus I composed this lyric to send to them.

A few words on concealment and action:
can the cycles of birth and death ever be measured?

chunks.translated_text:
Unrelenting, the stubborn heart deludes with love and desire,
ever more manifest—
through endless ages, never reaching home.
Fortunate to meet Ancestor Chongyang,
who revealed the Quanzhen Way for transcending the world.
I send word to my clan: awaken,
ponder deeply—
this one has never borne the surname Wang.

**[To Cui Miaoxin]**
A true and luminous master,
vast as the Hongfan, wondrous in emergence.
Fragrance, taste, color, sound—none can cling,
know this well:
though waves surge, the shore stands unmoved.
Recognize this, let no doubt arise,
waste no effort chasing outward.
In sitting, lying, standing, walking—hold fast,
contemplate:
with every blink and brow’s lift, who is it?

**[Two Lyrics to the Tune "Qinlouyue"]**

**On the Pine**
A traveler of mist and clouds,
towering, hidden beside the secluded crag.
Beside the secluded crag,
frost oppresses, snow weighs—
yet not the slightest hindrance.
Gnarled branches sway beyond the cold clouds,
its natural form and substance truly lovable.
Truly lovable—
verdant, distinct,
a singular bearing.

**On the Bamboo**
Of steadfast purity,
supple branches and tender leaves fit for painting.
Fit for painting—
through all seasons, ever companion
to the thatched hall’s wind and moon.
Lofty and unyielding, its nature uniquely noble,
hollow-hearted, forever undecaying.
Forever undecaying—
green shade swaying,
auspicious tones, pure and exquisite.

**[Five Lyrics to the Tune "Fenglouwu"]**

**Mountain Dwelling, Idle Thoughts**
All around, green pines and bamboo.
Shaded and bright, the mountain home—
what care for idle honor or disgrace?
Alone, I chant and pour fine wine,
its rich flavor intoxicates; drunk, I sleep in my robes.
Awakening from a clear dream, desire remains unfulfilled.
Again I embrace the jade zither,
playing the melody of *No-Birth*.
Who is the knowing companion at my side?
The thatched hall’s wind and moon should approve.

**To Fellow Daoists**
Worldly affairs, tangled—what suffering they bring!
Death and birth, coming and going,
the wheel of reincarnation never ceases.
Fortunate to have perfected ones open the Dharma hall,
guiding people onto the path of *No-Birth*.
Travelers on this path, heed my words:
devote yourself sincerely,
cherish the Dao, forget thoughts and worries.
The work of clarity and stillness shines forth—
on the path of *No-Birth*, we shall ever meet.

**Exhorting the Springtime Wanderer**
Tender willows hang golden, blossoms burst open.
Everywhere in gardens and groves,
the sleeve-sweeping fragrance of wind delights.
Endless before the eyes, idle scenes—
only to adorn the splendor of spring.
Young riders gallop in lively throngs,
heedless of prosperity’s
stealthy change of rosy complexion.
In the end, emotion cannot endure—
earnestly I tell the flower-seekers this.

**Hearing the Oriole in Late Spring**
The fleeting light hastens—how swiftly it presses!
Bright sun, gentle wind,
again send spring’s light to dusk.
Gradually I hear the flowing oriole’s speech on the branch,
warbling as if pouring out its heart.
Yesterday, flowers bloomed red across the trees—
now they have scattered,
wildly chasing flying catkins.
I urge the wanderers to awaken to life:
do not lose the path you came by.

**Three Days Before Qingming, After a Light Rain, Presented to All**
Sever love, forget emotion—be ever vigilant.
The hare runs, the crow flies,
hurrying the passing years.
Again Qingming draws near—
every household’s smoke and fire must be guarded with care.
Harmonious qi, misty and dense, is precious fortune.
Fine rain hangs like a curtain,
not betraying spring’s promise.
Nature’s work continues thus,
immortal blossoms drifting, trailing fragrant tones.

*Using Zhang Ziyun’s Rhymes*

Attaining true leisure,

A life of quiet simplicity,
twenty years since I set aside the golden goblet.
Everywhere, turning the light inward,
dispelling darkness and confusion—
the spirit’s mirror is not bronze.
Sometimes I play
in the red dust’s realm,
sometimes I dwell in seclusion
beside green crags and pines.
Grasping the reins of Tan and Ma,
their legacy of style remains.
Driving the workings of creation,
naturally the tiger and dragon mate.
Ascending to the pure heavens,
how dare I linger in indolence to vie for first?

**II**
Abandoning fleeting glory,
forgetting entangling snares,
freer than autumn’s tumbleweed.
Delighting in Heaven’s mandate,
all encounters flow smoothly.
Following conditions, a single meal suffices—
what need for a thousand bushels of emolument?
Content in idleness, guarding simplicity,
enduring poverty’s clarity—
why care for stubborn bronze?
Accompanying cloud companions,
inviting wind and moon,
facing the creek’s stones,
before the crag’s pines.
Discussing the serene,
the family style of transcending the world.
Refining gold, cooking jade,
turning the female tiger and dark dragon.
Now, once more awakened,
all ties are empty—
the mind weary, the will indolent.

**Entering the Dao**
Death and life press,
the wheel of rebirth urges—
no respite from toil.
Toward the ford of delusion,
the bitter sea, all vie to race.
Meeting this sagely age,
true immortals descend teachings to deliver the lost.

**The Official Path**

The official path flows like water—
eastward, gains and losses never cease.
What matter prince or peasant?
The limit of impermanence arrives, none can stay.

Far better to cast off fame’s shackles,
to spare oneself vain sorrow.
One day, when the three cinnabar elixirs align,
I’ll ride the clouds to seek Penglai’s isles.

*Matching Master Sun Yuanming’s Rhyme*

Suddenly casting off worldly affairs,
I pass the boundless years in knowing fate.
Monopolizing the grass-thatched hall’s wind and moon,
serene—yet to whom could I boast?

In this life, I hold fast to freedom,
nurturing cinnabar in the precious tripod.

will I drift as a dweller of the sea-girt isles.

On the Double Ninth, joy runs deep—

Enhancing refined pleasure,

heart honoring the Three Luminaries,

chunks.original_text: 云水生涯，到处为家。 远浮名、浮利浮华。 三宫升降，上下无差。 要结灵胎，收灵物，聚灵芽。 清兴幽赊，此外何加。 恣陶陶、畅饮流霞。 大丹熟也，归泛仙槎。 便曳琼琚，摇琼佩，戴琼花。 忆师父训号白云子名丹桂字昌龄 幼悟离尘，炼汞烹银。 把壶中、造化区分。 虎龙调处，滋助阳初。 现亘来容，元来面，本来身。 云水为邻，风月常亲。 妙玄通、方称全真。 忆师慈训，稍异常人。 便字昌龄，名丹桂，号白云。 示众复用前韵 说甚根尘，辩甚铅银。 这仙佛、路径明分。 何须外觅，不在劳神。 欲要全完，当全道，露全身。 一体同观，无起疏亲。 志常清、常静常真。 不惟自利，兼利他人。 定结祥光，成祥瑞，蹑祥云。 满路花四首 谢昌黎道友访及 早年忘俗累，云水寄天隅。 群峰藏弊舍，养痴愚。 寂寥孤淡，默默守如如。 深谢崇真友，步屦携笻，不辞远访山居。 奈门风、冷落清虚。 相待礼全疏。 微言频劝喻，省区区。 前程路险，认取妙元初。 物物头头上，一段灵光，本来无欠无余。 赠小崔评 人间何最苦，说着替君愁。 眼前生灭景，象悠悠。 虚名薄利，随分少贪求。 幸遇嘉时节，乘兴偷闲，访寻霞侣云俦。 更那堪、猛悟回头。 物外恣飘游。 布袍襟袖阔，好风流。 纷纷尘事，一笔尽都勾。 磨莹先天宝，灿灿辉辉，恰如朗月当秋。 岁日赠冯六等 节令频移改，寒暑递相迁。 光阴驹过隙，古今传。 晓来万户，欢笑贺新年。 谁肯回光照，绀发童颜，渐成衰鬓皤然。 愿人人、早悟根原。 搜觅妙中玄。 洞天风月下，舞胎仙。 刀圭潋滟，一颗大丹圆。 捧入青霄路，步步无生，任从海变桑田。 赠两山道友乌林答同监等 东南形胜地，极目锁岚烟。 海山锺异秀，产英贤。 人多吉善，息念屏嚣喧。 是处追朋挹，探妙赜真，共修物外因缘。 愿由斯、道念弥坚。 早早悟重玄。 殷懃营养就，火中莲。 清香馥郁，递互尽相传。 异日真功满，拂袖携云，径超无上人天。 月中仙二首 返照
chunks.translated_text:
**Cloud-Water Life**

A cloud-water life—wherever one goes, there is home.
Far from floating fame, floating profit, floating vanity.
The Three Palaces rise and descend, without deviation above or below.
Essential to bind the numinous embryo,
gather the numinous essence,
and assemble the numinous sprout.

Pure joys lie deep and distant—what more could be added?
Freely, joyously, drink the flowing rosy clouds.
When the Great Elixir ripens,
ride the immortal raft homeward.
Then trail jade pendants,
sway jade ornaments,
and wear jade blossoms.

**Remembering the Master’s Teachings**

The Master, styled White Cloud, named Cinnamon, sobriquet Everlasting—
from youth awakened to leave the dust,
refining mercury, smelting silver.
Grasping the transformations within the flask,
harmonizing tiger and dragon,
nurturing the nascent yang.
Manifesting the ever-present visage,
the original face,
the fundamental body.

Clouds and water as neighbors,
wind and moon as constant kin.
Only when the wondrous mystery is penetrated
is one truly called a Perfected.
Recalling the Master’s compassionate instruction,
slightly different from ordinary folk—
styled Everlasting,
named Cinnamon,
called White Cloud.

**Addressing the Assembly, Reusing the Previous Rhyme**

Why speak of root and dust,
debate lead and silver?
The path of immortals and buddhas
is clearly divided.
No need for external seeking,
no need to tax the spirit.
If you wish for wholeness,
fully embrace the Dao,
reveal the whole body.

View all as one,
without distinction of near or far.
Aspire to be ever pure,
ever still,
ever true.
Not only benefiting oneself,
but also benefiting others.
Certain to weave auspicious light,
achieve auspicious omens,
and tread upon auspicious clouds.

**Four Poems to the Tune "Flowers Filling the Path"**

**To Daoist Friend Changli Who Came to Visit**

In early years, I forgot worldly burdens,
dwelling among clouds and water at heaven’s edge.
Clustered peaks conceal my humble abode,
nurturing my foolishness.
Desolate and plain, silently guarding thusness.
Deep gratitude to the esteemed true friend,
who, staff in hand, did not shrink from the distant journey to my mountain retreat.
Alas, my gate’s wind is cold and desolate,
my hospitality crude.
Your subtle words, repeated admonitions,
awaken me from trivialities.
The perilous road ahead—
recognize the wondrous origin.
In every single thing,
a measure of numinous light,
inherently lacking nothing, needing nothing.

**To Little Cui**

What is most bitter in the human realm?
Speaking of it stirs sorrow for you.
The scenes of arising and ceasing before your eyes,
fleeting as shadows.
Empty fame, meager profit—
follow your portion, seek little.
Fortunately, in this fine season,
seizing the moment to steal leisure,
I seek cloud companions and rosy-cloud friends.
How much better to suddenly awaken and turn back,
roaming beyond the mundane.
With broad sleeves and flowing robe,
what elegance!
The myriad dusty affairs—
all swept away with a single stroke.
Polishing the precelestial treasure,
glittering and radiant,
just like the bright moon in autumn.

**On New Year’s Day to Feng Liu and Others**

The seasons repeatedly shift,
cold and heat alternate.
Time, a galloping steed through a crack—
so the ancients and moderns transmit.
At dawn, ten thousand households
laugh and celebrate the new year.
Who would turn their light inward,
to see youthful dark hair
gradually turn to hoary white?
May all people early awaken to the root and source,
searching for the mystery within the wondrous.
Beneath the grotto-heaven’s wind and moon,
dance the immortal embryo.
The alchemical spoon brimming,
a single Great Elixir perfected.
Holding it, ascend the azure sky’s path,
step by step beyond life and death,
heedless of seas turning to mulberry fields.

**To Daoist Friends of the Two Mountains: Wulin, Da, and Others**

The southeast’s scenic land,
gaze afar, mist and haze locked in embrace.
Sea and mountains gather rare beauty,
yielding outstanding worthies.
People here are auspicious and kind,
calming thoughts, silencing clamor.
Everywhere, companions gather,
exploring the wondrous and profound,
together cultivating otherworldly causes.
May from this, devotion to the Dao grow ever firmer,
awakening early to the profound mystery.
Diligently nurturing,
the lotus in the fire.
Pure fragrance, rich and lush,
passed on without cease.
One day, when true merit is complete,
sleeve swept, clouds in hand,
directly transcend the supreme heavens of humans and gods.

**Through kalpas of benighted delusion,**
bound by the snares of love and attachment,
long have I clung in blind obsession.
Vying for precedence, jostling for rank—
watching the towering waves and surging tides,
how could I heed the peril of drowning?

Fortunate now to awaken,
I brush my sleeves, open my heart,
and roam with unbounded joy.
Reflecting on past affairs,
every step and trace of my journey
now appear as grievous foes.

Lightly I become a man of leisure,
beneath the shadows of green pines,
amid the drifts of white clouds.
Content and at ease,
I pass the days in song, laughter, and conversation,
flowing with circumstance.
As evening deepens, refined delight grows—
facing the mirror of heaven,
its limpid azure vast and clear.
One by one, the silver toad ascends,
radiant, leaving the traces of the Three Isles behind.

**Gazing at the Sea**

The summer’s heat now wanes,
gradually clouds withdraw from the four wilds,
mountains and seas gleam in clarity.
From on high, I cast my gaze—
beholding the boundless ocean,
eastward stretching without end.
Vast and still, wind and waves at peace,
again and again manifesting
auspicious omens and blessings.
Great is the primal form of the Mysterious Origin,
serene and vast,
floating with the power of heaven and earth.
Its divine workings and sacred might defy measure,
trusting in the turning of the归墟,
ceaseless and unending.
Expanding the myriad transformations,
clouds and creatures soar,
fish and dragons play.
Blending the beauty of a thousand ages,
concealed within the Three Isles,
the wondrous realms of the Ten Continents.
Only when merit is complete at last
shall I ride the whale, laughing and carefree,
transcending beyond all.

**Two Poems to the Tune "Joy of Meeting Heaven"**

*Attainment*

Awakening to the illusory shifts of floating life,
swiftly cast aside love and attachment.
Unwashed face, disheveled hair,
clad in hemp and paper,
adrift to the ends of sea and sky.
Breaking strength, blunting sharpness,
embracing softness, weakness, and poverty,
forgetting sorrow, forgetting shame.
Even the stubborn mule and restless ape
suddenly cease, vanishing without trace.

A touch of the wondrous, profound principle—
facing the limpid azure heavens,
it bears the flavor of another realm.
*Lalā-lī-lā*, lips singing, tongue loose,
what restraint or hindrance remains?
Again and again, I bow in reverence,
grateful for my teacher’s guidance
in years past.
One day, I shall follow,
joining the Peach Banquet together.

**To Cai Dehou**

By a thousand means and ten thousand expedients,
you have revealed the path of cultivation,
one by one.
The supreme Dao is profound and obscure,
its subtle mechanism distant and elusive—
it demands utmost diligence and toil.
Fleeting as the blossoms of spring,
mindful of the precious turning of fortune’s wheel,
how can one bear to waste it in vain?
This karmic connection,
once lost, is hard to encounter again.

Hear my earnest exhortations:
return to the familiar ground of old,
scrutinize carefully, lest error arise.
The candle of nature shines bright,
the flower of the heart blooms resplendent,
unfolding boundless pure fragrance.
Act thus,
and naturally the lofty immortals
will secretly bestow their protection.
When merit is complete and the work perfected,
you shall step onto the path of cinnabar clouds.

*Fishing at Wulin: To the Second Young Master*

This life’s grandeur is the karma of past lives,
clearly explained to the worthy.
Turn your head early, awaken to the root,
lest the mundane world entangle you.

Search the secret, visit the profound,
refine mercury and lead within the furnace.
When true merit and true practice fulfill the three thousand,
you shall ascend as a great immortal.
